newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast prods ease with NYMEX, despite bulls.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast prods ease with NYMEX, despite bulls.

text.p: U.S. West Coast product prices eased slightly as traders focused on weaker futures, briefly offsetting a generally bullish forecast for the region, as maintenance season begins.
October gasoline on NYMEX closed 1.74 cents lower Thursday at 61.32 cents a gallon amid concerns about imports and higher stocks.
Locally, key refiners such as Chevron, El Segundo, and Arco were under repairs of preparing for maintenance, while regional stocks of gasoline remained at relatively low levels of 26.9 million.

Traders heard rumors of a possible deal between Ultramar and small Powerine refinery, located in Santa Fe Springs, Calif. Under the rumored terms, Ultramar would own crude and gasoline which mothballed Powerine would process for a fee.
No date was set for the potential pact, despite rumors of late September start-up at the refinery.
But a trader familiar with Ultramar's supplies said the oil company had not bought any additional crude for October.
Conventional or "clear" grade gasoline in Los Angeles fell a cent to 66/67 cents a gallon. Discounts for San Francisco grade widened a cent to two cents below L.A. material.
And Premium conventional in L.A. was nine cents over regular on ongoing problems with key Mobil gasoline unit.
Ultra-clean CARB gasoline in L.A. gave back two cents to hit 70.50/71 cents a gallon.
Deals for October and September cost nearly the same, as business shifted to the later month.
Bids for CARB diesel in L.A. were flat at 76/77 with low sulphur at off about a cent to 70.50/71.50 cents.
Distillates are expected to soften, with cargoes expected soon.
